questions.question: Which of the following statements are false regarding primary lung abscesses?

options.B: Hematologic dissemination is one of the causes
options.C: Poor dental hygiene is an independent risk factor for developing lung abscesses
options.D: Staphylococcus aureus can cause lung abscesses in individuals with alcohol use disorder.

questions.explanation: Lung abscess: Aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions Dental/periodontal infection Frequent vomiting Intubated patients Patients with tracheostomy Necrotizing pneumonia Immunodeficiency Causes of Primary Lung abscesses: In the majority of cases, the pathogen responsible is polymicrobial , often consisting of anaerobic bacteria such as (Option A ruled out) Bacteroides Prevotella Peptostreptococcus Fusobacterium A monomicrobial lung abscess is typically caused by Streptococci Staphylococcus aureus Klebsiella pneumoniae Streptococcus pyogenes Burkholderia pseudomallei Hemophilus influenzae type b Nocardia Actinomyces In individuals with alcohol use disorder , the most frequently identified organisms responsible for lung abscesses are Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Actinomyces. (Option D ruled out) Additionally, poor dental hygiene is a significant independent risk factor for the formation of lung abscesses. (Option C ruled out) Pathophysiology : In most instances, primary lung abscesses result from the aspiration of oropharyngeal contents containing anaerobic bacteria. These primary lung abscesses usually begin as aspiration pneumonia. If untreated, they can develop into pneumonitis and then progress to tissue necrosis (lung abscess) within 1 to 2 weeks. Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4543327/ www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555920/

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with fever, productive cough, and pleuritic chest pain. A chest CT scan reveals a fluid collection in the pleural space with a thickened pleura. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A lung abscess, on the other hand, is a localized collection of pus within the lung parenchyma. Pneumonia involves inflammation of the lung tissue and may or may not lead to pleural effusion, while pulmonary edema is due to fluid accumulation in the lung interstitium, not the pleural space. Empyema (Option A): Empyema is a collection of pus in the pleural space, which can vary in consistency, as thin as serous fluid or so thick that it is impossible to aspirate. Microscopically, it shows a high number of leukocytes. It can be unilateral or loculated/encysted, usually secondary to infection in neighboring structures (commonly the lung) , most often due to bacterial pneumonia or tuberculosis. Chest X-ray may resemble pleural effusion, but pleural adhesions may create a ‘D’-shaped shadow. Ultrasound or CT helps identify the fluid’s location, extent of pleural thickening, and whether it’s single or multiloculated. Aspiration is done using a wide-bore needle; thick, turbid pus confirms empyema. Fluid characteristics suggestive of empyema: Glucose < 3.3 mmol/L, LDH > 1000 IU/L, pH < 7.0. Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics and surgery to drain pus and expand the lung. Lung abscess (Option B): A lung abscess is a localized pus collection within the lung parenchyma, typically >2 cm, containing necrotic debris or fluid. It can be acute (<6 weeks) or chronic (>6 weeks). Primary lung abscesses result from aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions, while secondary lung abscesses arise from conditions like bronchial obstructions (tumors, foreign bodies) or existing lung diseases (bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis). Chest radiographs show a thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level; CT imaging offers better definition and earlier detection of cavitation. Pulmonary abscess. Case study, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 13 Dec 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-8533" data-hash="8955" data-license="NA" data-source="https://radiopaedia.org/cases/pulmonary-abscess" data-tags="" height="344" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/LxGJwVaXyhB9dsS6ROpM1744318797.png" width="348" /> Empiric antibiotic therapy is the main treatment; abscesses >6-8 cm may require surgical or percutaneous drainage due to poor resolution with antibiotics alone. Pneumonia (Option C) typically affects the lung parenchyma and may show consolidation on a chest X-ray or CT. However, it does not usually involve a fluid collection in the pleural space. Pneumonia can lead to pleural effusion, but it would not typically show the thickened pleura and loculated fluid collection. Pulmonary edema (Option D) involves abnormal accumulation of extravascular fluid in the lung parenchyma. It can be broadly classified into cardiogenic and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. Cardiogenic pulmonary edema shows central edema, pleural effusions, Kerley B lines, peribronchial cuffing, and an enlarged heart. In noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, the pattern is typically patchy and peripheral, with ground-glass opacities and consolidations with air bronchograms.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with a productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray reveals a lobar consolidation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of community-acquired pneumonia in this patient?
questions.explanation: x-ray is suggestive of community-acquired pneumonia . The most common causative organism of CAP is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumonia can be classified into 2 types based on how the infection is acquired: Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) Community-acquired pneumonia: Diagnosed in non-hospitalized patients or a previously ambulatory patient within 48 hours after admission to the hospital. Causative organisms: Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common) , Mycoplasma, Legionella, Chlamydia, Haemophilus influenzae (Option B ruled out) , etc. Hospital-acquired pneumonia: Defined as pneumonia that occurs 48 hours or more after hospital admission and is not present at the time of admission. Diagnosis should be considered in any hospitalized or ventilated patient who develops purulent sputum (or endotracheal secretions), new radiological infiltrates, an otherwise unexplained increase in oxygen requirement, a core temperature > 38.3°C, and a leucocytosis or leucopenia. Causative organisms: Aerobic gram-negative bacilli (e.g. Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option D ruled out) , Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option A ruled out) , Enterobacter spp, Acinetobacter spp) and gram-positive cocci (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, which includes methicillin-resistant S. aureus, Streptococcus spp). Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1010-1020 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 582-585 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430749/ https://www.nc bi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK535441/#:~:text=Introduction,present%20at%20the%20admission%20time.

questions.question: A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with a non-productive cough, dyspnea, and low-grade fever. A Gomori methenamine silver stain of a bronchoalveolar lavage specimen was done. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) , a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients. Co-trimoxazole is the first-line treatment for PCP. PCP is the leading cause of AIDS-associated morbidity in patients with CD4+ T lymphocyte counts of <200/ µ L who are not receiving ART or PCP prophylaxis. The primary symptom of PCP is progressive shortness of breath lasting less than 12 weeks. Dry cough and fever are frequently observed. Chest X-rays typically show diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar and symmetric. HRCT scans reveal characteristic diffuse ground-glass opacities . Pneumatoceles can develop and may rupture, leading to pneumothorax. Diagnosis is confirmed using methenamine silver stains, PCR, or immunofluorescence on bronchoalveolar lavage or induced sputum, as spontaneously produced sputum has low diagnostic yield. Prophylaxis and treatment involves high-dose co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), with systemic glucocorticoids added if the patient is hypoxic. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1691-1695 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 315, 318

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with fever, cough, and chest discomfort. His chest X-ray reveals right lower lobe consolidation. Which of the following features would be more consistent with atypical pneumonia?

options.A: Gradual onset with a dry cough

questions.explanation: interstitial infiltrates on X-ray. Typical pneumonia presents with fever, cough, sputum production (may or may not be present) and lobar consolidation. Typical Pneumonia: Causative organisms: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, Group A Streptococcus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella, anaerobes, and gram-negative organisms. These organisms can be easily cultured on standard media or seen on Gram stain. Clinical features: Fever, cough, sputum production (may or may not be present). Bacterial pneumonia mostly presents with mucopurulent sputum. Constitutional symptoms such as fatigue, headache, myalgia, and arthralgias can also be seen. Radiology: Typical bacterial pneumonia is usually lobar pneumonia. Atypical Pneumonia: Also known as walking pneumonia , often presents in ambulatory patients who come to outpatient departments with mild manifestations. Causative organisms (most common): Mycoplasma pneumoniae (associated with close living conditions like at school and military barracks), Legionella (from stagnant water sources or from air conditioners), Chlamydophila pneumoniae and Coxiella. Clinical features: Gradual onset and have a viral prodrome including a sore throat, headache, nonproductive cough, and low-grade fevers. Radiology: They rarely have an obvious area of consolidation on auscultation/imaging compared to pneumococcal pneumonia. Additionally, extra-cardiopulmonary symptoms are often seen; for example: Mycoplasma pneumoniae: GI symptoms may be present. The drug of choice is Azithromycin. Legionella pneumophila: URTI (Pontiac fever), Legionaries' disease (spread by water droplets), associated with SIADH. Hyponatremia with seizures. Chlamydia pneumoniae: Contact with birds. Influenza A: H3N1 ,H1N1, RSV, adenovirus, COVID -19 Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1253, 1441, 1452 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532239/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534295/

questions.question: A 70 y/o man with COPD presents with 3 days of worsening shortness of breath, fever, and productive cough. He appears confused and has a respiratory rate of 32/min, BP of 85/55 mmHg, and BUN of 25 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate management?

options.B: Inpatient treatment with levofloxacin and azithromycin
options.C: ICU admission with piperacillin-tazobactam and vancomycin

questions.explanation: with tachypnea and hypotension all align with the diagnosis of Pneumonia. This patient has a CURB-65 score of 4 (confusion, uremia, respiratory rate > 30, and hypotension), indicating the need for ICU admission and more intensive therapy. Given his comorbid condition (COPD) and the potential for aspiration and Pseudomonas infection, the recommended treatment is a combination of anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (piperacillin-tazobactam) and vancomycin for MRSA coverage. Treatment for Lobar Pneumonia Treatment depends on severity; assess if inpatient or outpatient management is needed. CURB-65 Score: Used to stratify patients with the following factors: CURB-65 Symptom Score ( C ) Confusion 1 ( U ) Urea: BUN >19mg/dL (>7 mmol/L) 1 ( R ) Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min 1 ( B ) Blood Pressure – Systolic BP ≤ 90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤ 60 mmHg 1 ( 65 ) Age ≥ 65 years 1 Hospitalization Criteria: CURB-65 score 0: Outpatient treatment Score 1 or 2: Indicates hospitalization Score ≥ 3: Indicates ICU admission and more intensive therapy. Empiric Therapy: Outpatient: No comorbidities: Monotherapy with macrolides (azithromycin, clarithromycin). With comorbidities (chronic lung/heart disease, diabetes, smoking, HIV): Newer fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gemifloxacin) or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., amoxicillin) and a macrolide. Inpatient Non-ICU: Newer fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) alone or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., ampicillin, ceftriaxone) and a macrolide. Inpatient ICU: Combination of macrolide (azithromycin) or newer fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin) with beta-lactam (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam, ertapenem). If risk of aspiration, consider ampicillin-sulbactam or ertapenem; for Pseudomonas infection, use anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam) with anti-pseudomonal fluoroquinolone (e.g., ciprofloxacin). For MRSA, add vancomycin or linezolid. Duration of Therapy: Typically 5 to 7 days, extended if clinical response is delayed. Influenza Treatment: All hospitalized patients testing positive for influenza should receive oseltamivir, regardless of illness onset. Outpatient treatment with azithromycin (Option A): Not appropriate for this patient due to his high CURB-65 score of 4, indicating he requires more intensive treatment. Outpatient therapy is suitable for lower-risk patients without significant comorbidities. Inpatient treatment with levofloxacin and azithromycin (Option B): While this option provides effective coverage for pneumonia, it does not account for the patient's need for ICU admission due to the severity of his condition (confusion, hypotension, elevated BUN). Inpatient treatment with amoxicillin alone (Option D): Inadequate for this patient due to the severity of his illness and the risk of resistant organisms. Monotherapy with amoxicillin does not provide sufficient coverage for his condition, especially considering the possibility of Pseudomonas and MRSA.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding breath sounds?

options.A: Vesicular breath sounds are soft, low-pitched sounds heard at the bronchus
options.B: Bronchial sounds are loud, high-pitched best heard at lung bases of normal lung
options.C: Egophony is the increased resonance of voice sounds heard when auscultating the lungs
options.D: Whispered pectoriloquy rules out the presence of lung consolidation

questions.explanation: the lungs the quality of voice sounds when auscultating the lungs, typically heard in areas of consolidation. Breath sounds: Feature Bronchial Sounds (Option B ruled out) Vesicular Sounds (Option A ruled out) Origin Tracheobronchial tree Finer lung parenchyma Characteristics Loud, harsh, high-pitched Soft, low-pitched Timing Predominantly expiratory Predominantly inspiratory Location Heard over the trachea or right apex Best appreciated at posterior lung bases Abnormality Abnormal if heard in other areas Normal in healthy lung areas Egophony is the increased resonance of voice sounds heard when auscultating the lungs. When spoken voices are auscultated over the chest, a nasal quality is imparted to the sound which resembles the bleating of a goat. Egophony is an auscultatory finding due to a change in the quality (timbre) of the voice. A solid (consolidated), fluid-filled, or compressed lung decreases the amplitude and only allows select frequencies to pass through. (Option C) This changes the sound of the vowel “E” to "A. Whispering Petriloquy: Whispered vocal sounds (“one, two, three” whispered repeatedly) are also used to detect a change in sound transmission (whispered pectoriloquy) and are more sensitive than voice sound transmission for early detection of pulmonary consolidation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: A 65 year old man presents to the ED with a 5-day history of fever, productive cough, and worsening shortness of breath. On examination, he exhibits tachypnea, and his sputum is thick and yellowish. He complains of sharp pleuritic chest pain when taking deep breaths. The physician notes increased vocal fremitus and egophony on examination. Based on the clinical features presented, which of the following findings is most likely to be noted upon auscultation of this patient’s lungs?

options.D: Presence of crackles and bronchial breath sounds

questions.explanation: and signs of consolidation (increased vocal fremitus and egophony) suggest lobar pneumonia . Auscultation is likely to reveal crackles and bronchial breath sounds, which are characteristic of this condition. Clinical manifestations of Lobar pneumonia: Common Symptoms: Fever Cough Sputum production (often mucopurulent) Pleuritic chest pain Sputum Analysis: The colour and quality of sputum can indicate microbiological aetiology. Localized pleuritic pain is common, especially in lobar pneumonia. Constitutional Symptoms: Fatigue, headache, myalgia, and arthralgias may occur. Severe pneumonia can lead to: Dyspnea. Confusion, sepsis, and multi-organ failure. Clinical Signs: Tachypnea (increased respiratory rate) Increased vocal fremitus Egophony (E to A changes) Dullness to percussion Auscultation Findings: Presence of crackles or rales, and bronchial breath sounds (tubular type breathing). (Option D) Oxygenation and Severity: Respiratory rate correlates with oxygenation; hypoxia leads to hyperventilation in severe cases. Absence of breath sounds (Option A): This is unlikely in lobar pneumonia. While there may be decreased breath sounds in the presence of significant pleural effusion, the scenario suggests consolidation rather than fluid accumulation. Ronchi (Option B) are a low pitched sound usually associated with secretions or obstructions in larger airways, like in bronchitis or COPD. Dullness to percussion (Option C) may be noted if there is pleural effusion, but it is not the primary finding in lobar pneumonia, where increased vocal fremitus and localized signs of consolidation are more typical. Reference: Typical Bacterial Pneumonia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A 25-year-old student presents with a 10-day history of dry cough, mild fever, and fatigue, but has been able to attend daily activities. Chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and a physical exam reveals mild crackles. Which of the following is the LEAST likely causative agent of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: mild symptoms and the ability to continue daily activities despite the infection. Klebsiella pneumoniae is least likely as it typically causes more severe, hospital-acquired pneumonia, unlike the mild presentation of walking pneumonia. Atypical Pneumonia (Walking Pneumonia) Definition : Atypical pneumonia is a milder form of pneumonia, often caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae , certain viruses, or moulds. Symptoms : Common symptoms include cough, fever, chest pain, headache, and chills, resembling a bad cold. It is generally mild, not requiring bed rest or hospitalization, allowing people to continue daily activities—hence the term "walking pneumonia." Etiologic Agents : Atypical pneumonia is caused by organisms that don't grow on standard cultures or appear on Gram stain , such as: Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option A ruled out) Chlamydia pneumoniae (Option B ruled out) Legionella species (Option C ruled out) Respiratory viruses: Influenza, adenoviruses, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), human metapneumoviruses, and coronaviruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2) Prevalence : Cases of atypical pneumonia are increasing, particularly among young adults. Diagnosis : These pathogens cannot be cultured in the usual ways, making diagnosis more complex. PCR and other molecular methods are often necessary for confirmation. Treatment : Atypical organisms are resistant to β -lactams (e.g., penicillins) and require treatment with macrolides, fluoroquinolones, or tetracyclines. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1010,1011 www.lung.org/blog/what-is-w alking-pneumonia#:~:text=Bed%20rest%20or%20hospitalization%20are,hence%20the%20term%20%22walking. %22

questions.question: A 70 y/o male with a h/o DM presents to the ER with a persistent cough, high fever, and shortness of breath. He recently returned from a week-long cruise in the Caribbean. O/E, he has decreased breath sounds on one side, and a chest X-ray reveals infiltrates that are suggestive of pneumonia. Given the patient's history and recent travel, which of the following is the most likely causative organism for his pneumonia?
questions.explanation: risk for Legionella species . Pneumonia Etiology and Common Pathogens Main Pathogens : Bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa. Typical Bacteria : Streptococcus pneumoniae , Haemophilus influenzae , Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA). Atypical Bacteria : Mycoplasma pneumoniae , Chlamydia pneumoniae , Legionella species Viruses : Influenza, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), coronaviruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2). Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP) Atypical Pneumonia Outpatients Hospitalized Patients Includes M.pneumoniae C.pneumoniae, and Legionella species. Common causes: S.pneumoniae, M.pneumoniae H. influenzae, C.pneumoniae, Respiratory viruses(influenza, RSV). Non-ICU ICU Patients Similar pathogens to outpatients, plus Legionella species. Pathogens include S.pneumoniae, S. aureus (including MRSA), Legionella species, gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae. Specific Pathogens in Certain Conditions: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) : Can cause CAP, often complicating influenza infections. Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) has emerged as a significant cause of necrotizing pneumonia. Pneumococcal Pneumonia : Higher risk in elderly patients, and those with comorbidities like dementia, heart failure, cerebrovascular disease, alcoholism, smoking, COPD, and HIV infection . CA-MRSA Pneumonia : More likely in patients with prior skin infections or following viral illnesses. Enterobacteriaceae : Common in patients recently hospitalized, those treated with antibiotics, or those with comorbidities like alcoholism, heart failure, or renal failure. Pseudomonas aeruginosa : Found in patients with severe structural lung diseases such as bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, or advanced COPD. Legionella Infection : Associated with risk factors like diabetes, hematologic malignancies, cancer, severe renal disease, HIV, smoking, male gender, and recent travel (air conditioners, shower, hotels, cruise ships). It is an important cause of atypical pneumonia. Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A): Although a common cause of pneumonia, it does not have a specific association with recent travel or cruise ship outbreaks. Haemophilus influenzae (Option C): Generally causes respiratory infections but is not typically associated with outbreaks linked to cruise ships or recent travel. Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Option D): More prevalent in younger populations with mild respiratory symptoms, making it unlikely in this older patient with significant comorbidities. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1010,1011

questions.question: Which of the following represents the correct order of pathological stages in classic pneumonia? → Gray Hepatization → Red Hepatization → Resolution Stage → Red Hepatization → Gray Hepatization → Resolution Stage → Red Hepatization → Edema Stage → Resolution Stage → Resolution Stage → Edema Stage → Gray Hepatization
questions.explanation: → Red Hepatization → Gray Hepatization → Resolution Stage classified into community-acquired (CAP), hospital-acquired (HAP) and ventilator-associated (VAP) Pathophysiology of Pneumonia Microbial Proliferation : Pneumonia arises from the growth of pathogens in the alveoli and the host's immune response. Lung Microbiota : The lungs harbour a complex microbiota; pneumonia can occur when this balance is disrupted. Infection Mechanisms : Pathogens reach the lower respiratory tract via inhalation, micro aspiration, or direct mucosal dispersion, bypassing immune defences. Triggers and Feedback : Viral infections or macro aspiration can initiate pneumonia; inflammatory responses may promote bacterial growth, worsening the condition. Immune Response : While the immune system typically contains infections, persistent inflammation can lead to full-blown pneumonia. Respiratory Effects : Inflammatory mediators cause fever and neutrophil accumulation, leading to capillary leaks, hypoxemia, and impaired oxygenation, which can worsen dyspnea and cause respiratory failure. Pathology of Pneumonia Patterns : Lobar Pneumonia Commonly associated with bacterial CAP. Patchy opacification evolves into homogeneous consolidation of affected lobe Air bronchogram (air-filled bronchi appear lucent against consolidated lung tissue) may be present Bronchopneumonia Typical in nosocomial pneumonia. Typically patchy and segmental shadowing.

questions.question: A 45 y/o man with a history of bronchiectasis presents for follow-up after sputum analysis reveals Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection. What is the recommended treatment regimen for this patient's infection?
questions.explanation: clarithromycin), rifampin, and ethambutol. This combination is essential for effectively treating MAC infections and preventing the development of drug resistance. Treatment of Bronchiectasis Antibiotic Treatment : Acute Exacerbations : Target common pathogens ( Haemophilus influenzae , Pseudomonas aeruginosa ) for at least 7–10 days. NTM Infections : Complex treatment with specific diagnostic criteria, requiring multiple positive sputum cultures and histopathological evidence. Regimen for MAC : For macrolide-sensitive MAC in HIV-negative patients: macrolide + rifampin + ethambutol. Bronchial Hygiene : Enhance secretion clearance with hydration, mucolytics, bronchodilators, hyperosmolar agents, and chest physiotherapy. Pulmonary rehabilitation and exercise Use mucolytic dornase (DNase) in CF-related bronchiectasis; avoid it in non-CF cases. Anti-Inflammatory Therapy : Inhaled glucocorticoids may reduce dyspnea and sputum production; with limited effect on lung function or exacerbation rates. Consider oral/systemic glucocorticoids for bronchiectasis due to ABPA and autoimmune diseases. Itraconazole may benefit ABPA patients. (Option A ruled out) Refractory Cases : Surgical resection for localized suppuration; lung transplantation for advanced bronchiectasis. Complications : Recurrent infections can cause antibiotic resistance and severe hemoptysis, requiring intubation, identification of bleeding sources, and possible bronchial artery embolization or surgery. Prevention : Address immunodeficiencies with gamma globulin, vaccinate against influenza and pneumococcus, and consider suppressive antibiotics (daily oral, rotating schedules, macrolides, inhaled, or intermittent IV) for patients with recurrent infections. Macrolide + Isoniazid + Ethambutol (Option C): Isoniazid is primarily used for tuberculosis treatment and is not recommended for MAC infections. Rifampin + Isoniazid + Pyrazinamide (Option D): This combination is used for tuberculosis treatment, not for MAC infections, and does not include the necessary macrolide. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2175, 2176

questions.question: A 30 y/o woman with a history of recurrent lung infections presents to the emergency. She reports increased sputum volume and a change in sputum colour. O/E, she demonstrates wheezing and crackles. What does the change in sputum production most likely indicate?

options.A: Initiation of effective airway clearance therapy
options.C: The onset of remission in chronic lung disease

questions.explanation: deterioration of the underlying condition . This change indicates an exacerbation of bronchiectasis due to heightened infection and inflammation. Symptoms like fever, malaise and anorexia can also occur. Bronchiectasis Symptoms Physical Examination Findings Persistent Productive Cough: There is thick, copious sticky sputum due to impaired mucociliary clearance. Shortness of Breath (Dyspnea) Pleuritic Pain or Discomfort Hemoptysis Fatigue and Weight Loss Acute Exacerbations: Increased sputum volume and purulence indicate worsening infection or inflammation. Crackles and Wheezing: Commonly heard during auscultation, crackles suggest alveolar involvement, while wheezing indicates airway obstruction. Clubbing: Enlargement and rounding of the fingertips. Initiation of effective airway clearance therapy (Option A) : While airway clearance can increase sputum production temporarily, it does not change the sputum's colour significantly, nor is it associated with new wheezing and crackles. The onset of remission in chronic lung disease (Option C) : Remission would generally result in improved symptoms, not an increase in sputum or change in colour. Onset of allergic reaction (Option D): While allergic reactions can lead to respiratory symptoms, they do not present with increased purulent sputum. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2132, 2174 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 579

questions.question: Which of the following is commonly associated with bronchiectasis affecting the lower lobes?
questions.explanation: because aspirated material (especially when lying down) tends to settle in the posterior segments of the lower lobes due to gravity. Repeated aspiration causes chronic inflammation and infection , leading to permanent bronchial dilation (bronchiectasis). Lobe Involvement in Bronchiectasis Upper Lung Fields Mid Lung Fields Lower Lung Fields Central Airways Cystic Fibrosis (Option A ruled out) Post-radiation Fibrosis Nontuberculous Mycobacterial (NTM) Infection (Option C ruled out) Dyskinetic/ Immotile Cilia Syndrome. AAT-1 deficiency Brocks syndrome Yellow nail syndrome Chronic Recurrent Aspiration : Conditions like esophageal motility disorders result in aspiration. (Option D) End-stage Fibrotic Lung Disease: Traction bronchiectasis as a result of parenchymal distortion and fibrosis. Hypogammaglobulinemia Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) (Option B ruled out) Congenital conditions that primarily impact the central airways: Tracheobronchomegaly (Mounier-Kuhn Syndrome) and Williams-Campbell Syndrome Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2173

questions.question: A 40 y/o man, a non-smoker, presents with shortness of breath, chronic cough, and repeated respiratory infections. His chest CT shows emphysema and bronchiectasis. Lab results indicate low alpha-1 antitrypsin levels. What is the most likely reason for the bronchiectasis seen in this patient?

options.B: Recurrent infections due to defective chloride transport
options.C: Impaired ciliary function leading to mucus retention
options.D: Increased neutrophil elastase activity causing damage

questions.explanation: of larger airways. In alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency , there is a lack of antiprotease , which normally inhibits neutrophil elastase , an enzyme that breaks down elastin in lung tissue. Without sufficient alpha-1 antitrypsin, neutrophil elastase can damage the lung parenchyma, leading to emphysema (Panacinar) and bronchiectasis as the airway walls become dilated. Idiopathic airway dilation (Option A): While idiopathic causes occur in significant bronchiectasis cases, low alpha-1 antitrypsin levels in this patient point toward an underlying mechanism related to protease-antiprotease imbalance. Recurrent infections due to defective chloride transport (Option B): It is seen in cystic fibrosis, where mutations in the CFTR gene lead to the production of thick mucus due to abnormal chloride and sodium transport across epithelial cells. This thick mucus obstructs the airways leading to chronic infections and bronchiectasis. Impaired ciliary function leading to mucus retention (Option C): This mechanism occurs in primary ciliary dyskinesia (eg. Kartagener’s syndrome), where dysfunctional cilia fail to clear mucus, resulting in mucus buildup and recurrent infections that can lead to bronchiectasis. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2174 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 550

questions.question: A 35 y/o female with asthma presents with worsening cough, wheezing, and episodes of hemoptysis. Chest imaging reveals central bronchiectasis, and blood tests show elevated total IgE levels and eosinophil count. What is the most likely cause of the bronchiectasis?
questions.explanation: in patients with asthma. It results from a hypersensitivity (Type 1) reaction to Aspergillus species, leading to central bronchiectasis . The features of increased IgE levels, eosinophilic count and asthma in the patient point to ABPA as the cause. Causes of Bronchiectasis Congenital Causes Acquired Causes Other Causes Cystic Fibrosis : Causes thick mucus build-up in the lungs, leading to recurrent infections and diffuse bronchiectasis. Ciliary Dysfunction Syndromes : Conditions like primary ciliary dyskinesia and Kartagener’s syndrome cause defective mucociliary clearance, resulting in bronchiectasis. Primary Hypogammaglobulinaemia : Low antibody production leads to repeated infections and airway damage, causing bronchiectasis. Severe Infections : Childhood infections like whooping cough and measles can damage airways (Usually cystic type). Pulmonary Tuberculosis : Can result in both focal and diffuse bronchiectasis. Suppurative Pneumonia Inhaled Foreign Bodies : Obstruction causes localized bronchiectasis by preventing clearance beyond the blockage. Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) : An allergic reaction to Aspergillus mainly causing central airway bronchiectasis. Bronchial Tumours : Can obstruct airways. Idiopathic : Accounts for a significant proportion of cases. Rheumatoid Arthritis Cystic fibrosis (Option A): It causes widespread bronchiectasis, particularly affecting the upper lung lobes, and is commonly associated with thick mucus production, malabsorption, and other systemic signs. Primary ciliary dyskinesia (Option B): It leads to diffuse bronchiectasis and is often associated with recurrent sinusitis and situs inversus (Kartagener’s syndrome). It is not linked to central bronchiectasis, asthma or elevated IgE. Idiopathic bronchiectasis (Option D): Idiopathic bronchiectasis is diagnosed when no cause is identified after a thorough investigation. Since the patient has asthma and tests point toward ABPA, idiopathic bronchiectasis is ruled out. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1679, 2165, 2173, 2174 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 578
